input: (In order to investigate the process of MeHg accumulation in rice, four experimental plots of rice plantation were carefully designed. The first plot was a control site paddy (CS-P) consisting of a rice paddy field located at Huaxi (control site) receiving a comparatively low Hg input by atmospheric deposition. This field with low soil Hg concentration (THg: 0.29 ± 0.023 mg kg1) was irrigated with the local drinking water containing a low concentration of Hg (THg: 5.4 ± 1.9 ng L'). The second plot was a control site-box (CS-B) (dimension 1.5 × 1.5 × 0.4 m), located at Huaxi, but filled with topsoil (0—10 cm) collected from a Hg-contaminated paddy field (THg: 30 ± 1.1 mg kg1) in Gouxi. This box received the same irrigation water as CS-P. The CS-B was situated beside the CS-P but was mounted on the roof about 2.5 m above the surrounding ground in order to avoid any contamination from soil particles by splashing during heavy rainfall. Both CS-P and CS-B received a low Hg input by atmospheric deposition throughout the growing season. The third plot was an artisanal site paddy (AS-P) located at Gouxi with a high Hg soil concentration (THg: 11 ± 3.4 mg kg-). This area receives an elevated Hg input through atmospheric deposition (both wet and dry deposition). The paddy was irrigated with streamwater contaminated with Hg (4200 ± 4900 ng L'). The fourth plot was an artisanal site-box (AS-B) with the same dimension as the CS-B and filled with topsoil (0- 10 cm) collected from the Huaxi paddy field with a low level of Hg (THg: 0.44 ± 0.028 mg kg). This box was placed adjacent to but above (mounted on a roof 2.5 m high) the surrounding ground in order to avoid any contamination from soil particles by splashing during heavy rainfall. The plants in the box were irrigated with the local drinking water containing low levels of Hg (14 ± 2.7 ng L-1). Both AS-B and AS-P received a high atmospheric Hg depositional flux characteristic of the Gouxi area.)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['Four experimental plots were designed to investigate MeHg accumulation in rice. The plots varied in soil Hg concentration and irrigation water, ranging from low to high Hg inputs, to study the effects of different environmental conditions on MeHg levels in rice plants.']}

Six levels of urea fertilizer (0, 189, 229.5, 270, 310.5, and 351 kg/ha) were implemented. For every urea fertilizer level, three fields with identical cultivation conditions were used as replicates. The fields were designed as randomized blocks. instruction: Identify the main event type and provide a summary of the event from the given text. The result should be presented in a dictionary format where the key is the event type and the value is a summary of the event.
input: (The soil and rice samples used in this study were collected from the suburbs of the main cities of Fujian Province, China. They include Fuzhou, Longyan, Ningde, Nanping, Sanming, Zhangzhou, and Quanzhou. Fujian Province is in southeast China, located between 24°22'-27°38'N latitude and 117° 52'-120° 13' E longitude. The average annual temperature and rainfall are between 17 °C and 21 °C and from 1100 to 2000 mm, respectively. As in the other regions of south China, rice (Oryza sativa) is the most important food crop in Fujian Province. Most of the paddy rice fields are derived from alluvial deposits that were distributed on alluvial plains alongside rivers. In total, 153 rice samples (ear samples) and 153 corresponding surface soil (0-20 cm depth) samples were collected. A total of 15 rice varieties were used in this study and they include Yi-you 673 (hybrid, indica), Yi-xiang 2292 (hybrid indica), Yi-you 115 (hybrid, indica), Pei-za-tai-fen (hybrid, indica), Fen-liang-you 1 (hybrid, indica), Te-you 009 (hybrid, indica), Tian-you 998 (hybrid, indica), Yue-you 9113 (hybrid, indica), Dong-lian 5 (conventional, indica), Yang-liang-you 6 (hybrid, indica), Jia-fu-zhan (conventional, indica), Te-you 627 (hybrid, indica), II-you 3301 (hybrid, indica), II-you 673 (hybrid, indica), and Yong-you 9 (hybrid, indica-japonica). For each sampling plot, 3-5 subsamples of the rice ears and the corresponding surface soils were collected and then aggregated into one sample for further treatment and analysis. Samples were placed in clean plastic bags and transported to the laboratory in the shortest possible time for treatment. The rice grains were air dried and dehusked. The air-dried brown rice was ground with a stainless steel mill to create particles < 0.5 mm for further analysis. The soil samples were air dried at room temperature and crushed with a wood roller to pass a 2-mm sieve. A small portion (about 30g) of the 2-mm soils was ground into fine powder (< 0.149 mm particles) using an agate mortar and was then used to determine the total concentration of heavy metals.)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['Soil and rice samples were collected from various locations in Fujian Province, China, for a study involving 15 different rice varieties. The samples were processed and analyzed to determine the total concentration of heavy metals, contributing to a broader investigation of tungsten bioavailability and accumulation in rice.']}

input: (The LGC-1 was bred from the progeny of a cross between a low-glutelin line NM67 which had been selected from the mutant lines using ethyleneimine treatment, and Nihonmasari (Nishimura 2002). LGC-Katsu was developed from a cross between LGC-1 and a 26-kDa-globulin-deficient mutant from irradiated Koshihikari. input: (Pre-germinated rice seeds were sown on 18 April 2003 in nursery boxes (Minoru pot 448, Minoru Industrial Co. Ltd., Japan) with 448 holes (16 diameter, 25 mm depth). A single seed was sown per hole. Then all holes were filled with nursery soil for rice seedlings (Pete-baido, Minoru Industrial Co. Ltd., Japan) The seedlings were transplanted manually on May 13 in a paddy field (gray lowland soil) at the Nishifukatsu field of the National Agricultural Research Center for Western Region, one pot in each hill, with hill spacing of 0.30 m by 0.25 m (density: 13.3 hills m?). Seedlings at the 4.6-4.9 leaf age were transplanted. Randomized block design with three replications was adopted to locate the plots. The plot size was 12 m?. Nitrogen, phosphate, and potassium oxide fertilizer, each at 4 g m, was applied as basal dressing. At 27 days after transplanting, 2 g m? of nitrogen was applied as topdressing. For LGC-Katsu, 4 g m? of nitrogen was applied as topdressing at 60 days after transplanting. For Nihonmasari, LGC-1, and LGCsoft, 4 g m? of nitrogen was applied as topdressing at 63 days after transplanting. At plant maturity, 42 hills (3.2 m') were harvested from each plot and brown rice grains greater than 1.80 mm in thickness were prepared as experimental materials.)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['Rice seeds were sown and transplanted in a structured trial at the National Agricultural Research Center for Western Region. The trial involved detailed management of planting density, fertilization, and specific treatments for different cultivars like LGC-Katsu, Nihonmasari, LGC-1, and LGCsoft, with the aim of studying growth under controlled conditions.']}
